conclusion: The problem involves analyzing the \\( U-I \\) characteristics of a silicon photocell and a resistor to find the internal resistance of the photocell.

The graph shows two lines: line \\( a \\) representing the \\( U-I \\) characteristic of the silicon photocell and line \\( b \\) representing the \\( U-I \\) characteristic of the resistor \\( R \\).
The intersection of lines \\( a \\) and \\( b \\) occurs at a current of \\( 0.2 \, \text{A} \\) and a voltage of \\( 2.5 \, \text{V} \\).
At the intersection point, the current through both components is the same, and the voltages add up to the total voltage supplied by the photocell.
The open-circuit voltage \\( U_{\text{oc}} \\) of the silicon photocell is approximately \\( 3.6 \, \text{V} \\).
The internal resistance \\( r \\) of the silicon photocell can be calculated using the formula \\( r = \frac{U_{\text{oc}} - U}{I} \\).
Substituting the known values into the formula gives \\( r = \frac{3.6 \, \text{V} - 2.5 \, \text{V}}{0.2 \, \text{A}} = 5.5 \, \Omega \\).
The internal resistance of the silicon photocell is \\( 5.5 \, \Omega \\).
